description.narrative: Most farmers still lack adequate knowledge of climate-smart agriculture and sustainable environmental practices, which further increases their vulnerability, as well as the risks to agriculture and the environment. Some community members continue to follow environmentally harmful practices, i.e., cutting down trees, slash and burn, flood irrigation and forest degradation. There is also widespread use of and dependence on synthetic fertilisers and harmful chemicals in crops and soils, which hinders the soil’s capacity to retain moisture and nutrients. This training therefore aims at supporting the target communities address these issues as part of resilience building. CSA includes proven practical techniques such as mulching, intercropping, conservation agriculture, crop rotation, integrated crop-livestock management, agroforestry, improved grazing and improved water management. It also involves the introduction of innovative practices such as more dependable weather forecasting, early-warning systems and climate-risk insurance. The climate-smart agriculture concept reflects the ambition of further integrating agricultural development and climate responsiveness.

The proposed RSA interventions from ICRISAT, CIMMYT and CTDO clearly respond to the training capacity needs of rural households in the project area. The programme will come up with alternative options to alleviate lack of qualitative data on low adoption of RSA practices through a systematic assessment and documentation of the current RSA practises. Training of trainers will be conducted in each of the ZRBF districts through the existing consortia. The programme would source/use the most qualified available human resource expertise within the ICRISAT, CIMMYT and CTDO to train the frontline extension staff and lead farmers on RSA that are local specific. With respect to backstopping, the programme will come up with a robust monitoring system to support extension staff cascading RSA practices to farmers.
